reviewText: This movie is destined to be forgotten as yet another stud in the studios' loser belt for summer of 2005. Part of this was due to the prepondrance of remakes, which in turn was due to the studios' refusal to risk anything and try to hedge their bets by green-lighting projects with presumably built-in audiences. My rant over, if you're here, you're probably inclined to buy the movie. To be perfectly honest, this was a below-average cookie-cutter comedy, but it only really starts to tank in the second half. The first half highlights Will Ferrell's antics as a vain, faltering movie star who agrees to take on a retooled version of the classic titular TV show, but only if he's the focus of it. In addition, there is lots of good supporting talent, such as Jason Schwartzman, Michael Caine, The Daily Show's Stephen Colbert and Steve Carrell. Sadly, the movie never quite congeals. The modern remake entails one of two approaches: either make everything the same, only with new faces (i.e. Psycho, SWAT, etc.) or engage in in-jokes, postmodern trickery, and so on. The latter group includes such landmarks of modern cinema as Starsky & Hutch. The problem with Bewitched is that it tries to do both. The everything-the-same approach necessitates that Nicole Kidman really be a witch, and the in-jokes portion includes plenty of showbiz-type absurdities that work much better on paper than on film. As soon as the studio-mandated love story kicks in, the humor has pretty much ended.Hopefully, after the drought of '05, studios will think twice before green-lighting lackluster remakes. Will Ferrell's moments alone are worth renting the movie, and it avoids being a complete piece of crap, like The Honeymooners remake. However, remaking one of the most beloved TV shows in history is a tall order, and I give the filmmakers credit for at least trying something different. Note to Nora Ephron: You've Got Mail, Michael, and now Bewitched together make three strikes. You're officially out.

reviewText: This schizophrenic movie adaptation of the beloved sitcom is disappointing on many levels.  The cast is fine and hit their marks, but they don't have much in the way to inspire them.Basically this interpretation is almost too clever for its own good.  It revels in a deconstructive approach and although it's fairly entertaining at times, I would have preferred a straight rendition of everyone's favorite magical suburban housewife.  When generous clips of Elizabeth Montgomery and the original cast are shown, you can't help but get nostalgic about the old show.  The delightful banter and familial friction between Endora & 'Derwood' was one of the many reasons the show worked so well and it's sorely missed here.  When you throw out so much of the old, to bring in the hipper new, something is definitely lost in the transformation.  And not to be overly cynical, but with today's TV DVD sets outselling many films, you can't help but wonder if a lot of this production wasn't dressed up as a big commercial for the classic sitcom with so much product placement served up as legitimate story fodder.  Indeed, the recently released DVD is packaged with an "exclusive separate disc with 4 episodes of the TV series."  Isn't marketing wonderful?When Michael Caine turns to Nicole Kidman and says something about him being a witch, it's just one of those little things they forgot.  Isn't he a Warlock?  Didn't Isabelle go on and on about the horrors of dating those bad, egotistical Warlocks?  Oh, I know it's the SAME THING only a different NAME - gender roles and all that being considered.Bewitched is just the opposite.  It's the SAME NAME - but a different THING from the TV show.  It may be your cup of tea or witch's brew as the case may be.  For me, I'll stick with the old sitcom anytime.

reviewText: I will admit right off the bat that I have never seen the original television show, so maybe that alone explains why I didn't loathe this movie as so many others have.  I have nothing to really base hatred off of.  I actually found this film to be slightly funny and overall very entertaining.  Nicole Kidman and Will Ferrell work really well together.  I've never really thought of Nicole Kidman as `funny' but she delivers here in a very unexpected and charming way, and while Ferrell is not his zany best he is still hilarious in scenes and worthy of mention.`Bewitched' is less a remake and more a film about a remake.  That is probably the first thing that must be said about this movie.  In the end it has many similarities to a remake but it is not technically a `remake'.  The movie is about an actor, Jack Wyatt, on the verge of being washed up.  He needs to make an impact and soon before he loses all control over his career and becomes a has-been.  He has a genius idea of remaking the classic beloved television show `Bewitched' and, in an effort to draw attention to himself, he decides to cast a nobody in the lead as Samantha.  This `nobody' is Isabel Bigalow who just so happens to be a witch who, much like Samantha, just wants to be a normal person.Isabel decides to take the offer but upon hearing that Jack only wanted her to make him look good she decides to get even, never imagining that she'd fall in love with him and visa-versa.Parts of the film don't work and I will say that the funniest gags in the film are stolen from some other slightly funnier movies but they still work here despite their familiarity.  Will Ferrell and Nicole Kidman work hard to make the dialog work and their relationship seem genuine.  Kidman embraces her characters naivety as well as her impish charm and Ferrell sinks deep into his characters conceited chauvinist nature.  Michael Caine and Shirley MacLaine are a bit lost here.  They don't have much to do and were most likely approached to add some appeal to the baby boomer crowd, which is a shame since they could have been used a little fuller in my opinion.  The real gem here though is Jason Schwartzman who is just hilarious as Wyatt's agent Ritchie.  He is the perfect supporting character here, adding layers of funny and delivering his lines brilliantly.  From the minute he appears on screen you wish he would show up in every scene.The film is far from perfect but it's also far from a putrid waste of time as many would have you believe.  Like I said though, I have never seen an episode of the beloved show and so I cannot say for sure if my opinion would be different had that not been the case.  I can see how some would have expectations for a film claiming to be the remake of a classic but if you watch this, not as a remake, but as a family comedy then you can easily find yourself entertained, and in the end that's all we want right, to be entertained.
summary: I don't know what all the fuss was about; I thought it was kind of funny...

reviewText: Today, I got up and just decided that I really wanted to see Bewitched. Of course I was skeptical! It's a movie that's based on an old TV show... are those ever good? The answer is, usually not. But Bewitched is a fun, light, romantic comedy, in true Nora and Delia Ephron style that will make you leave the theater smiling. My biggest qualm with this movie is that it's a bit slow, but Ferrell and Kidman more than make up for that with their amazing chemistry.Kidman plays Isabel, a witch who just wants to live a normal life. Her father Nigel (Michael Caine... so funny!!) discourages her from doing this, telling her not to hide from her true self. She, of course, ignores his warnings, but just can't seem to kick the magical side of herself. As she strolls through Bed, Bath and Beyond, she smiles at a couple arguing about paint-- "I want to argue about paint!" she says. However, she ends up paying for all her new towels and kitchen utensils with a tarot card. "That's my last thing as a witch," she says to her father. Meanwhile, actor Jack Wyatt (Ferrell) is struggling to get back his acting career. He decides to star in a remake of the TV show Bewitched, and on the advice of his assistant (Jason Schwartzman), makes lots of ridiculous demands-- "Go make me twenty capuccinos and bring me the best one!" He wants to cast an unknown in the role of Samantha, finding Isabel one day in a bookstore (she wiggles her nose so well!) and begging her to be his TV wife. She agrees, but learns that it's difficult to work with a demanding jerk... whom she really likes.It's such a funny movie, I definitely recommend it. I wasn't the only one laughing out loud throughout this movie! In many ways, it is the typical romantic comedy... but throw in a witch played by Nicole Kidman and the hilarious Will Ferrell... well, that's a great movie right there!

reviewText: How do you take a gem of a premise (that *anything* can happen) and turn it into an unfunny comedy?  I loved watching Bewitched as a kid and when we were 13 or so, my best friend and I used to bounce Bewitched ideas off of each other with "what if" premises.  Some of these had us laughing in stitches.  For example, what if Endora mistakenly thinks "Derwood" is having a little hanky panky with a secretary and she poxes him by making his genitals completely disappear.  He discovers this when he goes to the urinal and he can't find the goods.  Of course Larry is at the next urinal wondering what's wrong.  Next scene, Darren's doctor is mystifed and asks him, "how do you pee"?What I was looking for was not so much a movie that honors the original characters.  I didn't care if there was an Uncle Arthur or an Aunt Agnes who stayed true to character.  I wanted the movie to stay true to the concept: that being the humor in silly and seemingly impossible things happening to serious people.  The situation creates the humor.  You don't need a gag actor like Will Farrell for that.  Silly things happening to a Marx brother style goofball is too lame for my taste.  One irony I found is that in the Darren role, Farrel is playing a self-obsessed "it's all about me" actor, and it turns out that the movie is really all about him and his unfunny (for me) goofball antics.Be warned: this movie has not a single laugh-out-loud moment. Not even a single suppressed-chuckle moment.  It is a fatally flawed unfunny attempt at comedy, in which the writers failed to concoct any funny situations.  Being that the original Bewitched was written for tv in the 60's, there was a lot of material that was off-limits then that is now accessible to even a PG-13 movie (see example above).  This movie failed to capitalize on that.

Besides the obvious misstep of believing that utilizing romance when it's plainly obvious that the show is more appropriate as a comedy and should be focused as such, there's other problems.  At first Will Ferrell and the other movie directors spend 20 minutes searching for the perfect woman who can match the legendary Elizabeth Montgomery of the original Bewitched, and in particular a woman who can wiggle her nose the right way.  They want to recreate Bewitched.  This is where Nicole Kidman comes in since she auditions for/fits the role.  Little do they know she's actually a witch, however.  Then, they actually pretend to film episodes of Bewitched on the big stage while rehearsing.  By this point I'm thinking "Could the writers have possibly thought of anything more misguided?"The second half of the movie however, is when it all falls apart and the reality that no actual interesting storyline is ever going to occcur at all.  The second half is all about Nicole Kidman and Will Ferrell flirting with each other for WAY too long (like 45 minutes) and never accomplishing anything substantial the entire time.  They waste our time like it's never been wasted before.  I mean geez, at least they could have given Nicole plenty of interesting magic spells to toy around with!  Something other than... this.For a moment I thought the movie would improve when Nicole Kidman overheard the movie director and Will bad mouthing her behind her back (literally) and therefore became so upset that she desired to bring back the witch spells that she promised she'd never use again (because her objective is to be human like everyone else) but sadly I was wrong.  Nothing I'd never consider worthy of entertainment ever came of this.  The only thing that occurs from this point forward is that Will Ferrell grows increasingly obnoxious as he becomes closer to Nicole Kidman, so he spends his time being flirtatious.  And if you're a guy and you think Will Ferrell is incredibly unfunny, seeing him act this way will be *unbelievably annoying*.  I guess women find his character cute and that's probably why he got the role in this film, but I'm a guy- I think he's a terrible and overrated comedian.  Steve Carrell makes an appearance near the end... and it's garbage too.I actually had a dream last night about Elizabeth Montgomery.  I woke up, wanted to know if she was alive or dead, and found out she died 5 days before my mom died back in '95... on my mom's birthday.  Weird series of events there.  When I had the opportunity to watch Bewitched I thought this was some kind of strange coincidence like I was supposed to watch it.  I guess not!  Too bad this movie completely misses the mark.  I mean *completely*.  A must avoid!  I'm still shocked.  On a final note it should be said that I don't mind movie remakes of old TV shows... but they have to be comparable to the TV show to an extent which is clearly not the case here.

reviewText: Bewitched was an old favorite among childhood television shows. I grew up enjoying it as an after- school rerun and when I heard there would be a movie version of the television show, I was anxious to give it a viewing and see if it would offer the same acting chemistry and overall spark that made the television series such an enjoyable one.What I discovered is that this movie, while a nice effort on the part of the director and others involved, isn't quite the blockbuster film I had hoped it would be. The main thing that I found different about this film is that, contrary to my expectations, it isn't a full- length film based on the television show. Rather, it is movie about a group of actors and actresses who are getting together to create a remake of the television show. This makes it different from the other remakes released this year (or in past years), but it also makes it unique. I didn't think I would like it at first, but I found that the director did a pretty good job assembling everything together and depicting the different actors and actresses in their respective roles.Nicole Kidman and Will Farrell are the main stars in this film, playing the parts of two people- Isabel Bigelow and Jack Wyatt- who are invited to play Samantha and Darren Stephens respectively. Wyatt already has the part as Darren and he discovers Isabel in a bookstore where he sees her twitching her nose- just like Samantha used to do on the television series. He offers her the job and she accepts. There is one twist to this, however: Isabel really is a witch and her father, played by Michael Caine, really is a warlock. When Kidman goes to audition for the part as Samantha and discovers that the character she is playing is a witch, she thinks her secret has been let out- that everyone knows she really is a witch. Her responses to the acting dialogue add some good humor to the film and she seems like the perfect choice of actresses to play her role.This movie is basically a romantic comedy, with Kidman pursuing Farrell hoping to establish a relationship with a mortal man so that she can live an ordinary mortal life. In this respect, the film is similar to the television show. Kidman's nave character isn't very similar and most of the other cast isn't much like the characters from the show (except for Michael Caine). But it still comes together pretty well in the end, making for a good but not great motion picture. It isn't the excellent film I had hoped for, but director Nora Ephron deserves some credit for creativity and for making the film work in spite of its differences when compared to most remakes.

reviewText: Well-intentioned "homage" to the classic TV sitcom, with Nicole Kidman as a real-life witch who finds herself playing Samantha in a remake of the original "Bewitched" TV show.  Will Ferrell plays a washed-up actor in the Darrin role, with Shirley MacLaine as the flashy, eccentric diva, tackling the role of Endora.Isabel Bigelow (Nicole Kidman) is a witch trying to live as best she can without the aid of her magical powers, much to the dismay of her warlock father (Michael Caine).  Thanks to her nose-twitching prowess, Isabel is cast as Samantha in a prospective new TV update of `Bewitched', with faded matinee idol Jack Wyatt (Will Ferrell) as Darrin.  Jack and Isabel immediately strike up their own special chemistry, and the filming of `Bewitched' sails along quite smoothly.  Until Isabel discovers he is using her to further his flagging career.  So she turns to her very own Aunt Clara (Carole Shelley), and places a powerful revenge spell over Jack.  But could love really happen between a witch and a mortal...?Screenwriters Delia and Nora Ephron have turned the coventional idea of the "TV-to-Hollywood remake" on it's head.  This remake is really a story-within-a-story, and that concept alone gives the film a freshness and the ability to be a little more flexible than your straightforward remake.Fantastic performances all around (Kidman is delightful as Isabel/Samantha, Ferrell is a comedic cut-up as the big-headed Jack and flustered Darrin; and Shirley MacLaine gives us the epitome of the glamorous diva in full force as Iris/Endora).  Kristin Chenoweth is a scene-stealer as Isabel's next-door-neighbour, and Carole Shelley is an Aunt Clara you'll adore.  Amy Sedaris appears in a cameo, as Gladys Kravitz.

reviewText: First, a disclaimer: I've never seen an episode of "Bewitched" and I can't compare this movie to the show. I am reviewing the movie as it stands alone. That said, "Bewitched" is sometimes charming and entertaining, but it cannot sustain the conceit throughout its running time.Nicole Kidman plays Isabelle Bigolo, a witch who is trying to live a normal life (i.e. get by without using her magic), and who gets the role of Samantha on a "Bewitched" remake. Will Ferrell is Jack White, an egotistic, has-been actor who is trying to break back into the biz with a role as Darren. The running joke in the film is that life imitates art: Isabelle and the unknowing mortal Jack fall in love, just as Samantha and the knowing mortal Darren fall in love on the show. The problem with this film is that it can't sustain this idea and subsequently suffers from pacing problems after establishing this idea. The movie then becomes episodic, and while some of these episodes are charming (Isabelle and Jack's dinner date, Isabelle's talk with her father, the filming of the TV show), they feel too disconnected. The episodic structure of the movie therefore doesn't help the movie in terms of plot, but it does provide opportunity for good acting performances.Kidman is absolutely delightful in this movie: cheery, light, and charming. She can do the nose-twitch very well (although I obviously cannot compare it to Elizabeth Montgomery's, as I have never seen Bewitched the TV series) and is extremely likable as Samantha. She seems entirely relaxed in her role and wisely knows not to take herself or the movie seriously. Ferrell is his usual (somewhat) funny self, although he tends to stretch those laughs until his antics/histrionics aren't funny anymore. Michael Caine is excellent and lovable as ever as Samantha's dad - a caddish Cassanova of sorts. His ability to infuse wit, humor, charm, and childlike vigor (at the age of 72!) into his role is amusing and loads of fun to watch.I would only recommend this movie for fans of the actors/actresses involved and for people who don't mind the episodic nature (and somewhat poor pacing) of this movie. The movie can be delightful at times, but not enough times and not consistently.

reviewText: Even though I'm still struggling with the concept of Will Ferrell getting the opportunity to romance Nicole Kidman onscreen - and being paid buckets full of money, to boot - I do have to say that I enjoyed Bewitched more than I thought I would.  I'm not saying there is anything at all substantial to the film, though, because there isn't.  It's complete fluff - but it's funny fluff.  Ferrell is his typically hilarious bumbling self, Shirley MacLaine seems to really enjoy the chance to ham it up as Endora, and Nicole Kidman is - well, she's Nicole Kidman.  I was as surprised as anyone when she took the role of the new Samantha, but she's quite good and as becoming as ever - although this part certainly offered her no challenges whatsoever.  Everyone in this film is good - except Steve Carell, who proves beyond the shadow of a doubt that we will never see the likes of Paul Lynde again (which is probably a good thing).I'm no fan of remakes, especially when so many of them are rather abysmal and usually leave me feeling quite offended on behalf of a show I have loved since I was a child.  You have to give the filmmakers of Bewitched a little credit, though, for taking a different approach to this particular remake.  They don't just recreate the original characters and give them an embarrassing script to run with, they do a film about recreating the original characters.  Nicole Kidman isn't Samantha at all, she's Isabel Bigelow, the woman who plays Samantha in the remake.  Of course, Isabel is herself a witch trying to live a normal life.  Will Ferrell isn't Darren; he's Jack Wyatt, the guy who plays Darren.  When Isabel and Jack fall for each other, it's the whole Samantha syndrome all over again.  The plot sounds rather weak, doesn't it?  I told you this was pure fluff.Ferrell gets most of the laughs as a formerly successful movie actor trying to bounce back from a movie bust of Ishtar proportions; he's your typical me-centric actor who cares only about himself.  If his move to TV in the form of the Bewitched remake falls through, he knows he's all but done in the business.  That's why he insists that a complete no-name star as Samantha, one who won't mind the fact that he's stealing all of the spotlights.  He thinks he finds just the woman in Isabel, who is in turn attracted to Jack because he's such an emotional mess (which is exactly what she is looking for in her quest to live a normal life) - but of course he has no idea he's dealing with a real witch.  The rest of the film is completely predictable, of course, and the Ferrell-Kidman matchup doesn't seem to have a whole heck of a lot of chemistry, but it's good, playful fun that doesn't try to be anything more than that.  Shirley MacLaine and Michael Caine lend a fair amount of class to the act, but it's purely the comedy incorporated into the script that makes this movie go.The plot, besides being predictable, also has a few problems - I for one would never have given Isabel a real-life Aunt Clara, and the whole Uncle Arthur scene is just embarrassing to have to watch.  Ferrell's goofiness and Kidman's charm, though, prove strong enough to overcome the film's obvious faults.  As long as you go in expecting nothing more than some good laughs, Bewitched should not prove disappointing.

reviewText: If you take Nicole Kidman, Will Ferrell, Shirley Maclaine, Steve Carell and Michael Freaking Caine in a film together, you should wind up with something great.If you don't there must be a huge problem somewhere.In this movie, which features all of those fine actors and actresses but doesn't even quite reach "mediocre," I believe that the huge problem is the script. It is unfunny, pretentious, confusing and cliched.Bewitched concerns a failing actor (Ferrell) who looks to rejuvinate his career by starring in a remake of the old television series, Bewitched. Because the old series focused on the woman's role (Samantha, played by Elizabeth Montgomery), he wants to cast an unknown so that he can be the focus of the new series. He winds up casting Nicole Kidman's character because she is able to twitch her nose like Montgomery did. It turns out that Kidman is, herself, a witch in reality, who is, like the character Samantha, trying to escape the witchy-world and find love on Earth.Find that to be, well, "stretching it" a little? Yeah--it's that kind of movie.Along the way, we discover that another one of the actors in the film also happens to be a witch, though that plotline never gets resolved, and then we get to question reality altogether as Uncle Arthur, a character from the original television series, shows up inexplicably. While all of this could be zany and amusing, it really isn't because eventually, nothing makes sense. The thing that makes sense least of all is why anyone would fall in love with Ferrell's character, or how the movie makers could expect us to want Kidman to fall in love with him. Fans of the series should spend their time and money on collecting the series, which is available on DVD, too. Fans of Kidman and Ferrell will discover that both actors have made far superior films. reviewText: Nothing irks me more than a blown opportunity for rejuvenating a fondly remembered sitcom that evokes instant nostalgia among baby-boomers but somehow misses the point of why the original show was so beloved. It appears director and co-writer Nora Ephron, along with her co-writer and sister Delia, got caught up in their own cleverness. They start with an only-in-Hollywood conceit, focusing the story on the effort to remake the "Bewitched" sitcom rather than trying to update the odd goings-on at the Stephens household for the new millennium. I applaud the originality of the concept, but the execution falls so flat that I was sighing at what should have been. There is some mild amusement with the show business sequences, such as the poolside negotiation, the auditions, the cartoon opening refocused completely on Darrin, and Samantha's on-set witchcraft. However, the love story, in particular, in the last half-hour, nosedives into predictability compounded by the lack of chemistry between the leads.An otherwise stellar cast has been set adrift. As Isabel Bigelow, a real witch tapped to play Samantha, Nicole Kidman is inarguably beautiful but oddly disjointed doing a breathy Meg Ryan impersonation. Kidman is an actress who depends on her fierce intelligence to maximize her effectiveness in roles, but she seems so preoccupied with being child-like and vulnerable that she often comes across as a graduate of a special education program. What she most lacks is the sense of bemused irony and saucy knowingness that Elizabeth Montgomery naturally brought to the role, but frankly that would have been an impossible task anyway. Will Ferrell steals the picture as fading star Jack Wyatt, but it's a petty crime at best. The character is such a complete jerk that one wonders whether Isabel just enjoys being a victim. While quite funny at times (especially as Isabel's witchcraft mangles his dinner scene on the sitcom set), there is an air of desperation in his antics as if he was the after-dinner entertainment on the Titanic.Standing in for Agnes Moorehead, Shirley MacLaine has a role that consists of a series of grand entrances and unfortunately due to the role-within-role she plays, there is not much for her to do besides some empty canoodling with Michael Caine, who plays Nigel, Isabel's erudite warlock father. In separate sequences that seem to function as pure nostalgia, Carole Shelley lacks Marion Lorne's genuine befuddlement as pixilated Aunt Clara, and Steve Carell does a merely adequate Paul Lynde as jokester Uncle Arthur. And the movie unforgivably wastes Amy Sedaris as nosy Gladys Kravitz. In new roles, helium-voiced Kristin Chenoweth fares better as Isabel's man-hungry neighbor Maria, as does Jason Schwartzman who captures the requisite oiliness of Jack's sycophant manager Ritchie.The 1960's sitcom was really not that great, just silly fun with a sharp cast, but this movie makes it seem as profound as Shakespeare. Scenes from the show's first episode are interjected to remind us of its legacy, and Montgomery`s Samantha is deified absurdly in an animated glossy. Watching this movie at a sneak preview among a sea of giggling children, I was overcome with the depressing feeling that this movie was hobbled together by committee driven by the studio's profitability demographic profile. Unlike an Alexander Payne or even a David O. Russell, Ephron simply does not provide any distinctive point of view here that could have made it more memorable. It could have been either a sharp post-feminist tract using witchcraft as a proxy for female empowerment or a social comedy about discrimination or mixed marriages. Instead, the film is a synthetic and forgettable waste of talent. I pray there is no sequel in the works.
summary: Misdirected Misfire Needs Elizabeth Montgomery Badly

reviewText: Shame, shame, shame on Nora Ephron.Bewitched, for many of us late blooming Baby Boomers is a television series that holds a warm place in our heart. The lame actor playing Darrin casts an unknown for Samantha, but little does he know she (Nicole Kidman) is really a witch who only wants to be normal (just like the Samantha from the original television series). Not!Now, Isabelle has never heard about Bewitched before, yet she has a dotty old Aunt Clara who carries door knobs around in her pocket book (just like Aunt Clara on the old TV series). Bizarro world, huh?And Isabelle has an eccentric Uncle Arthur just like the television series...(Fortunately he only shows up at the end of the film in order to completely finish it off).Isabelle doesn't have a mother in the picture - only her father (Michael Caine, who sleep walks through his sad role). What about Endora you ask?Well, Shirley MaClain plays Endora - only she is really playing an actress named Iris, who is playing Endora in the television series. Or is she just that?Where's Dr. Bombay? What about Serina? Where's the witches council?I'm sure that the producers thought this film might spark off a sequel. I sure hope not. This first film is so horrible it could turn people off to the charming television series from the 60's.Michael Caine's "Daddy" keeps popping up on frozen food cartons and jars of dressing. In the television series, Maurice Evans' Daddy was a dignified Shakespeare quoting gentleman. Here, he is an Uncle Arthur knock off - which is weird since the producers bring in "uncle Arthur" later in the film.Endora, as a character in the new television series, played by Iris something or other (actually played by MacClaine) is a ham actress of former fame, who may or may not really be a witch (although she doesn't know Isabelle). She's a joke - and not a funny one. Agnes Moorehead's Endora was never a joke.The original television series succeeded so well, because the characters were clearly defined. It was very loosely based on the 1940's Veronica Lake film, "I Married a Witch". 1960's Bewitched used popular actors for the leads, but filled the supporting roles with well known, tried and true, well trained, dignified, and award winning character actors, like Agnes Moorehead - "Mother/Endora" (four times nominated for Academy Award), Maurice Evans -  "Daddy"(Tony award winning Shakespearean stage actor), Marion Lorne (a fine radio actress), David White as Larry Tate (a reknowned stage actor);Estelle Winwood and Reta Shaw (character actors extrordinaire); Bernard Fox (Dr. Bombay); and Paul Lynde (Uncle Arthur).It's a shame that the actors of merit in this film (Kidman, Caine, and MacClaine) are all wasted and play second fiddle to pitiful writing and sad direction and editing.I really can't imagine a more horrible re-visioning of the charming 1960's television series.This film doesn't deserve to even be associated with the name of that original series.

reviewText: 'Bewitched' is lots of fun, very funny at times, and features a much better cast than most films loosely based on old TV shows.  Nicole Kidman is PERFECT, not just in her looks and nose twitch, but in the personality she exudes of a non-actress witch (Isabel) playing Samantha in the TV show remake.  Director Nora Ephron also brings out the almost-but-not-quite-shy idealistic girl-next-door quality from Kidman that she got so perfectly from Meg Ryan in their films together.  And the "story-within-a-story" approach is better than trying to do a direct portrayal.That said, the movie does have a core problem to it that Ephron's other two smash romantic comedies -- 'Sleepless in Seattle' and 'You've Got Mail' -- did not have: It's really hard to like the lead male character for a lengthy portion of the film.  Will Farrell is HILARIOUS and does a terrific job playing the insecure, self-centered, and needy actor Jack Wyatt, but he's so overly pathetic for so long that it gets to be tiresome and annoying to watch him, rather than charming.  In 'Sleepless' and 'Mail', you get to know AND LIKE both lead characters even as you understand their differences, and the charm comes in watching them overcome the obstacles between them.  But in 'Bewitched', the only true obstacle between them is Wyatt's ongoing childish insecurity.  That insecurity is heightened and used by his smarmy agent, played well by Jason Schwartzman, but it simply takes a little too long for him to get his act together and go after the girl sincerely.Still, there's a lot of funny and clever material here -- a lot of it on the lips of Michael Caine, father of Isabel and self-styled ladies man who meets his match in Shirley Maclaine, an actress/witch named Iris who portrays 'Andora' on the show.  Also, Kidman shows a serious talent for comedy that I hope we'll see more of in the future.  And look for other fun from Steve Correll ('The 40-Year-Old Virgin') as Uncle Arthur, and Steven Colbert, now of 'The Colbert Report' on Comedy Central.Overall, Bewitched is a very good time, definitely worth seeing, and maybe even worth adding to your collection.  But don't be surprised if it's just a notch below the magic you were hoping for.
summary: Great Cast, Smart Idea, But Not Quite Magical

reviewText: BEWITCHED is a very pleasant movie.  Movie versions of television shows normally do not adapt well to the big screen, but this one did a fair job.  If you did not grow up watching the original "Bewitched" -- or follow the syndicated reruns -- then you would miss half the fun in this film.This movie initially took me by surprise.  The original teasers in the movie theater gave me the impression that this was going to simply be a remake of "Bewitched."  It is a little more complicated than that.  In the film, Nicole Kidman and Will Ferrell's characters are actors who in turn set out to play the parts of Samantha and Darrin Stevens in a revival of the old television series.  Surprise, suprise ... Kidman's Isabel Bigelow is actually a witch.  Ferrell's Jack Wyatt is Isabel's conceited co-star.  With a little help from Isabel, Jack overcomes his ego and falls in love with Isabel.  Can Jack accept the fact that Isabel is really a witch?  You will have to watch the movie to find out, though this debacle was similarly solved in the initial episode of the original "Bewitched" television series.BEWITCHED does not need this extra layer of story.  It would have been much better for Kidman to simply play Samantha and Ferrell to play Darrin.  Michael Caine does a superb job as Isabel's warlock father Nigel Bigelow.  He could very easily have been Samantha's father Maurice.  Caine's scenes in the supermarket are wonderful.  Unfortunately the movie within a movie format of this film prevents him from playing his part to full effect.Speaking of full effect, Shirley MacLaine is absolutely the modern version of Endora.  Oh, she is also playing the part of an actress playing the part of a witch.  By the way, she is also a real witch.  No doubt numerous comic opportunities were lost with the superfluous story.  In the original series, Endora was Darrin's nemesis in most of the episodes.  In this movie she is not actually Endora so there are no mother-in-law confrontations and spiteful spells.  MacLaine's brief appearances as Endora are stunning.Just when you finally accept that fact that Kidman and Ferrell are not really Samantha and Darrin, we discover that Isabel coincidentally has an inept Aunt Clara.  At other junctures Uncle Arthur and nosy neighbor Gladys and her husband Abner appear.  After all the effort to impress us that this film is not a remake of "Bewitched," the introduction of these familiar characters outside of the film within a film is confusing.As I noted earlier, it would have been much better to have launched this film with Kidman and Ferrell as Samantha and Darrin.There are some truly funny bits in this film.  At times Will Ferrell acts very much like his childish character in ELF.  Although I do recommend that you get this DVD, I gave the film three stars because of the unnecessary and distracting film within a film genre.

reviewText: Nicole Kidman is cute, Will Farrell is funny, and Nora Ephron wrote this movie (along with her sister, Delia), so it is rather surprising that "Bewitched" does not work anywhere near as well as it should.  They could have simply taken the concept from the classic 1960s situation comedy and translated it to the silver screen, but Ephron had what she thought was a better idea.  This would be a movie about the attempt to remake "Bewitched" as a television show, which would star the struggling actor Jack Wyatt (Ferrell) as Darren.  He demands a complete unknown to play Samantha, and discovers that Isabel Bigelow (Kidman) can twitch her nose.  He figures she is perfect for the role, but does not know that she really is perfect because she really is a witch.  This might be more irony than mere mortals can endure, but it is a different bit of a twist.The problem is that the character of Wyatt is the only person on the face of the Earth who does not know that the Samantha character is the star of "Bewitched."  Now, the idea that somebody who want to remake "Bewitched" but have the show focus on Darren instead of Samantha is a nice little joke, but like Steve Martin's gag about cat juggling it is not as funny when you actually try to show it.  We also have to pretend that everybody producing and working on this show are content to let it all be about Darren, which is really taking the joke way too far.  This leads us to the second part of the problem, which is that when we get to the romantic part of this romantic comedy it is more believable when Isabel tugs on her ear (real witches are like Carol Burnett apparently) then when we get to the point where Jack has a change of heart, brain, and probably several other body parts as well.  There is even a scene where Jack is talked into believing that what has happened was his own idea, which I think was an attempt by Ephron to convince us as well.When Isabel's Aunt Clara (Carole Shelley) shows up and is a lot like Samantha's Aunt Clara, whatever Ephron is trying to put together collapses.  My best guess is that there is something meta-critical going on here, but I still have not worked out what it would be in any way that would make sense.  By the time Uncle Arthur (Steve Carell) shows up, so to speak, I figure it is just because they are trying to touch all the bases, which means Gladys and Abner cannot be far behind (and they are not).  Still, I am haunted by the idea that Ephron was trying to come up with something that worked on several levels and that I cannot tell what she was going for before all those levels collapsed bothers me, especially because I would have bet Ephron was capable of carrying something like that out.Much has been made of Kidman's breathy speaking voice in this film but I did not find it bothersome and thought she was cute without becoming kewpie doll cute ala Marilyn Monroe or Betty Boop.  The idea of having Isabel's main relationship be with her father, Nigel (Michael Caine), made for a nice contrast with Samantha's relationship with Endora, and the casting of Shirley MacLaine as the actress who plays Endora was perfect, because it reminds us that Agnes Moorehead was in MacLaine's league, the same way that Montgomery and Kidman are on the same level.  This 2005 comedy certainly acknowledges the affection people have for "Bewitched" in general and Elizabeth Montgomery in particular.  I especially liked that the clips from the television series were all from the early black & white period before the show got a bit silly, because that was when Montgomery was at her best.  At the very least, this  "Bewitched" reminds everybody of how good she was.
summary: Kidman is cute, Farrell is funny, but what was Ephron up to here?

reviewText: This is a take-off of the popular television sit-com, "Bewitched", that originally starred the adorable Elizabeth Montgomery as a witch, Samantha Stevens, who is married to a mere mortal, Darrin Stevens, played by Dick York. The television show was a huge hit, and not even the eventual replacement of Dick York with another actor in the role of the husband made it lose any ground with its devoted audience.So, I looked forward to seeing this film, which, to its credit, tries to give the original premise a fresh look. So, the film is actually about a re-make of the original sit-com, with funny man Will Ferrell playing the part of Jack Wyatt, a down on his luck actor looking to give his faltering career a boost. When he is offered a chance to play the part of Darrin Stevens in a television re-make of "Bewitched", he leaps at the opportunity, on the condition that an unknown is cast in the part of Samantha, so that his own role is not eclipsed.When he spots gorgeous Isabel Bigelow (Nicole Kidman) twitching her nose in public, Jack is positive he has found the perfect unknown for the role of Samantha. Unbeknownst to Jack, however, Isabel really is a witch who is just trying to live an ordinary life, doing the things that mere mortals do. She is trying very hard not to use her unusual abilities and is looking for someone who wants her just for herself. When she meets Jack, she misreads his intentions and finds herself on cloud nine. She does the show, playing the role of Samantha, only to discover that Jack is not really the person she thought he was. Then, let the games begin!Nicole Kidman and Will Ferrell are both good in their respective roles, and Nicole Kidman really does have that nose twitch down pat, though her ostensible naivet' is a bit cloying. It is the supporting cast, however, that nearly runs away with the film. Michael Caine is wonderfully droll as Nigel Bigelow, Isabel's warlock father, who pops up when she least expects it. Shirley MacLaine gives a terrific, over the top performance as actress Iris Smythson, who is cast to play Samantha's television mom, Endora. Jason Schwartzman is excellent in the role of Ritchie, Jack's smarmy, sleazy agent. Kristin Chenoweth is adorable as Isabel's perky neighbor and new found friend. David Alan Grier, Heather Burns, and Steve Carrell round out the notables in the film.The film has plenty of star power and enough laughs to keep it plodding along, but its downfall lies in the script, which screenwriter Nora Ephron wrote, together with her sister, Delia. While I have to give them kudos for the new twist, in the end the film fails to fully satisfy the viewer, as it tries too hard to be all things to all people. The original "Bewitched" was a simple fantasy comedy. Now, the screenwriters have tried, unsuccessfully, to interject romance into the formula, making it a fantasy comedy with romantic overtones. Not only is there not enough chemistry between the two leads, the romance is simply unnecessary. Perhaps they should have stuck to the original premise. After all, if it ain't broke, why fix it?In any case, this is still a moderately enjoyable film that is certainly worth a rental.

reviewText: Jack Wyatt (Will Ferrell) has hit a career snag.  His last couple of movies have flopped at the box office and he desperately needs a hit.  The answer comes from a surprising place, a TV remake of the classic sit-com Bewitched.  Initially reluctant, he gets talked into it.  But he'll do it only if his co-star is a complete unknown.Enter Isabel Bigelow (Nicole Kidman).  She's just moved to LA and is in need of a job to pay for the house she's renting.  As chance would have it, the two meet one day at a bookstore, where Jack spies Isabel twitching her nose unconsciously.  He's immediately struck with her ability to recreate the original show's signature move, and talks her into being his co-star.There's just one thing Jack doesn't know.  Isabel is a real witch trying to give up her magic.  As his ego continues to run the production, she feels compelled to do little things to keep him in check.  Or big things if the need is called for.  And the two co-stars seem to be actually falling for each other as well.Unlike many of the straight remakes being done today, this one offers a cleaver twist, the remake within a remake.  This alone gives the movie an edge above many similar movies coming out every year.  And it really does need that edge.For the most part, the movie is a simple romantic comedy.  The plot complications may take on a different nature, but they aren't too different from the normal boy meets girl, they fight, they make up and live happily after ever storyline.  As always, it's how the movie carries it out that makes the difference.  This one entertains with lots of magic jokes and references to the original series.  We get to see lots of the original pilot remade, which is fun.  There are also a couple cameos by characters from the original series, even if played by different actors.All the actors do a fine job with their rolls.  Nicole Kidman is great as Isabel, an innocent trying to do without her magic.  I'm not normally a Will Ferrell fan, but his many personality changes as Jack were great to watch.  Shirley MacLaine and Michael Caine are outstanding in their supporting rolls.  And I must mention how much fun it was to see Kristin Chenoweth on the big screen as well.As is usual these days, the movie has been released in a special edition.  The movie is presented in wide screen and full surround.  Extras include the usual deleted scenes, director commentary, and outtakes.A masterpiece?  No.  But this movie is worth watching for an entertaining hour and a half or so.  Just sit back and enjoy the magic.

reviewText: I'm going to go ahead and assume that you're familiar with the original series starring Elizabeth Montgomery (since the movie does).  I'll also assume that you've heard at least a thumbnail of the plot in which Will Ferrell plays a hasn't-had-a-hit-in-awhile Hollywood actor who decides to resurrect his career by doing a revival of the old "Bewitched" show altered to highlight HIM as the leading man.  The "catch" is that when he insists on casting an unknown that he can tromp all over as Samantha he chooses Nicole Kidman who - is really a witch!If you throw in supporting characters played by the likes of Michael Caine and Shirley Maclaine, how could you go wrong?Why, by the script, of course.  And the direction.  The talented Nora Ephron, who did much better work on "Sleepless in Seattle" and "When Harry Met Sally", doesn't push this project along in a single direction.  Sometimes it's a silly farce.  (The funniest scene in the movie comes at a dry-run script read where Nicole hexes Will into some funny stuff.)  Sometimes it's a romantic comedy, and it is so formulaic that in the big "here's-my-surprise-oh,-don't-run-away" scene of the film I half expected that they would wind up with one character hot-footing it for a train station or airport with the other in hot pursuit. (as happens so often in unimaginative romantic comedies.) The "misunderstanding" portion of the film is resolved without a chase, but just as predictably as the worst romantic comedies you have seen.  Part of the movie is a satire on the big egos and the brown-nosers who feed the big egos in Hollywood - but these parts were totally unconvincing, and I think the parts were unconvincing "as written", although it could have been "as directed", but the fault is a moot point as both were Ms. Ephron. If you want to watch a movie where Hollywood sticks it to itself I recommend the much better "The Player" with Tim Robbins and guest-starring practically everyone in California who couldn't wait to poke fun at Hollywood. And where did the idea come from that a "losing heat Hollywood actor" would decide that the way to "comeback" would be to play "Darrin"?  Darrin Stephens was such a bland part that the original show moved along without skipping a beat when Dick York was replaced by Dick Sargent.Nicole Kidman pretty much nails her part - no complaints here.  Caine and MaClaine are delightful in their 10 minutes of screen time.  Ferrell is.... all over the place.  His "unhexed" Hollywood Actor personality is such a jerk and so over-the-top as a jerk that 1. he's just not believable (and as the "mortal" he's supposed to be the one you don't have to suspend disbelief for) and 2. I had a hard time rooting for him/them at the time that the movie only succeeds if you're rooting for him."Bewitched" is a mixed bag - recommended for Ferrell or Kidman fans or Bewitched fetishists.
summary: 4-Star Concept with 4-Star Cast Underachieves to 3 Star Movie

reviewText: I grew up with the Bewitched series and dearly loved it, then continued to love it in reruns for many years afterward.  For that reason, I was looking forward to seeing the Bewitched movie, but it turned out to be a bit of a disappointment.  While the remake-within-a-remake concept is original, it didn't go over too well.  Some parts of the movie were silly.  The whole idea of Isabel being a real witch who is chosen to play a witch on tv is corny.  Even cornier is that Isabel has an Aunt Clara in real life who is identical to the Aunt Clara on the Bewitched series, and that Mr. and Mrs. Kravits also turn out to be real, as they become Isabel and Jack's neighbors at the end (even though the scene is cute).  The part where Uncle Arthur is a figment of Jack's imagination is also silly and unconvincing, although Steve Carroll does an impressive impersonation of the late Paul Lynde.  In addition, the way Isabel uses her magic to get back at Jack when she's mad at him doesn't go over too smoothly.  Also, the total character turnaround of Jack from conceited, obnoxious actor to compassionate and humble nice guy is not very believable.  The ending is also tiringly predictable.  The beginning of the movie is good, as Isabel, tired of living life as a witch,  settles into a house (very cute how she turns a picture of a house into a real house for rent), goes shopping, and tries to adjust to living mortal life.  In a delightful twist, Isabel has a cat who is black with yellow speckles.  The scenes between Isabel and her father are excellent (Michael Caine is superb and very effective as Isabel's father).  However, after the part where Isabel is recruited to play Samantha, the movie goes downhill.  I agree with one of the other reviewers that this movie would have been much better if they had canned the remake-within-a-remake idea and had made an actual remake of the series with Nicole Kidman as Samantha and Jack Wyatt as Darrin.  Michael Caine and Shirley MacClaine would have both been brilliant as Maurice and Endora.

reviewText: I probably join the throng of Bewitched TV show fans whose cherished childhood memory is watching Bewitched. At about 7, I came under the Bewitched spell and loved the show.  When Bewitched the movie was released, I went to see it right away, hoping to recapture my childhood love of the TV show. Nicole Kidman was squeeze-ably nave in the role as Isabel Bigelow, the witch-turned-actress.  Will Ferrell delivered all the goofiness of Darrin, all the arrogance of a has-been movie star, and all the soul of a man in love.  (Will's character, Jack Wyatt, hopelessly falls for Isabel as, of course, does Darrin fall for Samantha).  One scene in which Jack (Will) is supposed to deliver one line instead turns into a verbal fiasco, thanks to Isabel's magic, and is one of the most side-splittingly funny scenes in any movie I've seen.Shirley McClain was superb as Endora.  Not only does Shirley resemble Endora, she also magically produced Endora's mannerisms, quirks and flair for the dramatic.  I'm pretty sure Steve Carell was channeling Uncle Arthur because he sounded like him, looked like him, and behaved like him flawlessly.The set is idyllic, the actors are amazing, and the story impeccable.  The recitation of spells and hexes are mildly unnerving to me, personally, but they're only a tiny fraction of the whole film.This is a delightful, sweet, funny and entertaining movie.  The only thing missing on the DVD is a blooper reel.  That would make it completely bewitching-in my opinion.

reviewText: I was really looking forward to this movie. I was a big fan of the TV show as a kid, and I'm a big fan of all the actors involved in the film, not to mention being a fan of Nora Ephron's work as a writer. But something was askew with this movie. It felt like a cake that didn't bake enough, and so it never really "rose." Nicole Kidman was luminous and did was required of her, but some of the writing had her looking like such an absolute idiot, and that baffled me. The TV Samantha was never stupid, and sadly, this film's version of that character (Isabel) was so removed from the mortal world that it seemed she had just arrived and no idea of "real life." I could almost buy that idea, but the character's behavior was just plain stupid at times and her quest for "real life" landed her in "reel life" which was so fake. Perhaps that was the point of the film, but it lent a very plastic feel to the whole thing and not enough depth to the supposed "real" moments. Poor Will Farrell seemed to be caught between the pompous and the absurd, and he seemed very uncomfortable with his role of leading man. And the supporting character actors were good but didn't seem to have enough to do, so there was almost a floundering feel. All in all, it just never "flew," which is sad to say for a witchy film.

reviewText: I was so looking forward to seeing this film, being such a huge fan of the original television series, as well as for the quality star line up it contained. Unfortunately, I found it to be sadly disappointing. Though I realize it's a difficult task to not only live up to the original, but also put an original spin on the concept, I found this to be a very weak half baked effort that just didn't seem to know where it was going and what kind of movie it was trying to be. Its concept of the life imitating art premise of an actress auditioning for a remake of the series, and who actually turns out to be a real witch, appeared interesting and promising but it just didn't get off the ground. Instead the characters, pasted on to a very wishy washy plot, turned out to be mere pale impersonations of the originals that weren't particularly funny, and just appeared thinly created and out of date.That was another problem with the film, it seemed very muddled, not really knowing which period it was in. Though Bewitched is a timeless comedy, it was made in a very different era of television that had an innocence and naivety to it which is out of place in this more sexually liberated but cynical of times. I don't see why the creaters behind this film could not have tried to bring it up to date more plausibly, especially given the technology and special effects available. I think it would have been very possible and provided a far more interesting result without doing a disservice to the original.Nicole Kidman is suitably cute and feminine and yes, definately has the nose twitch down pat. But she is no Elizabeth Montgomery and should have tried to make the 'Isabel' character more her own (and without that contrived sugary voice). Much better use could have been made of Michael Caine and Shirley Maclean, who were perfect for the 'Maurice' and 'Endora' roles but let down by a poor script and storyline. reviewText: No, it's not a bigscreen remake of the original 1960's/70's television series, and that's most likely the main reason 2005's "Bewitched" was not well received. Determined to avoid simply making a bigscreen version of the beloved television classic, the filmmakers here have actually created something rather original and just as entertaining while still staying true to the show's basic theme. A lovely young woman, who happens to also be a witch, does her best to give up her magical ways in order to find a nice but incomplete young man and settle down to a normal life. However, her introduction to suburban normalcy is shaken up when she meets a falling movie-star named Jack Wyatt in search of an unknown to play opposite himself in a new television revival of "Bewitched". Little does he know that Isabel Bigelow, the young lady in question, is a real witch. All he cares about is that she can wiggle her nose just like the original Samantha and also happens to look a lot like her. In need of a job and thinking Jack might be the perfect man for her, Isabel is talked into taking the role not knowing that Jack intends to make the show all about Darrin this time around. As one might expect, the spells begin to fly as Isabel attempts to earn her due respect and appreciation on the "Bewitched" set and in Jack's heart. And things really get crazy when the TV show characters begin to enter the real world to make sure everything works out right!Nicole Kidman stars as Isabel, the woman cast to play Samantha on the new "Bewitched", and she is absolutely adorable in this film. Love the bouncy hair and sweetheart personality; never more attractive! Will Ferrell is always enjoyable, here playing the role of oft-misled but good-at-heart Jack Wyatt, though this isn't a film that is all about him. It's totally a shared billing, and why audiences didn't see chemistry in this pair is beyond me. They are fantastic together, and this is a film with just a great cast over all. Sir Michael Caine plays Isabel's warlock father, Nigel, Shirley MacLaine is Iris, the actress cast as the new Endora, and Steve Carell pops in to play a magical incarnation of Uncle Arthur, just to name a few! It's a very sweet film that is loads of fun if you can get past that whiney insistence that a "Bewitched" movie has to be a remake. Don't get me wrong, I understand the desire for such a film, even if Director Nora Ephron didn't. Seeing updated, big budget, bigscreen versions of TV shows we loved in the past is great fun! The old talk about a feature starring Alicia Silverstone as Samantha and Jim Carrey as Darrin probably had a lot of people excited. I wanted to see that too, and Crispin Glover also would have made a great Darrin. Never would have thought about Will Ferrell, but since he's not REALLY Darrin here, it works, and Nicole Kidman probably really would have been a perfect choice for Samantha. Here, her personality is much more sweet and innocent, but then she isn't exactly playing Samantha and it's perfect for who she IS playing. The existing "Bewitched" movie took the subject matter and did something original with it, and it turned out wonderful, even if I would have loved to have seen a big budget take on the old show. If I were going to pick on anything, it would be the minimized and tardy explanation of the TV characters merging with the real world. Despite Uncle Arthur's exclamation, "Do I have to explain everything?!" the set up of actors portraying the old TV characters, but with real similarities, makes things confusing if you start bringing in the real characters without much explanation. I think this only doesn't bother me now because I have watched the film enough times, and all the bonus features, to be clear on it, but I can easily see how it would be an issue for many casual viewers. It's just a matter of paying better attention though, and doing a little open-minded/imaginative thinking, and it certainly adds to the fun. Another thing that adds to the fun are several excellent music selections! I even loved hearing Louis Armstrong singing Disney's "'Bout Time" in the closing credits!The DVD is great, with excellent widescreen picture, a fine director's commentary, deleted scenes and multiple featurettes, a trivia track (though you have to be a fast reader for this one), and a trivia game for fans of the original series. So, if you're interested in checking out a romantic comedy with a lot of magic and TV nostalgia, I highly recommend picking this one up! And especially if you're a fan of any of the stars! I'm not a hardcore Kidman fan, but she is a complete delight here, and particularly gorgeous!
summary: Sweet, Charming, Magical, Underappreciated Romantic Comedy

reviewText: There are so many things wrong with this film, it is hard to know where to begin.  First, it is a film adaptation of a hit television series, a genre of film that is consistently among the worst that exist.  Second, it is a poorly conceived adaptation.  Instead of making it a straightforward adaptation, the pretext of the film is that a real witch who is trying to give up her powers to settle down and marry a normal human being is miraculously cast in part of Samantha in a revival of the series BEWITCHED.  This is all fairly clever and I thoroughly approve doing a variant on show rather than a straight remake.  It worked for the quite funny films based on THE BRADY BUNCH (one of the few times where a movie was better than the TV show upon which it was based, though fans of the show might disagree with me), but unfortunately almost nothing else is clever.  I say "almost" because I did enjoy many moments when Isabel (Nicole Kidman).  The problem is that in the reconception, the pretense is that the actor who plays Darrin, Jack Wyatt (Will Farrell), is the lead in the show and not Samantha.  This is bad enough, but it is made worse by the wretched presence of Will Farrell in the role of Jack.  OK, I have to admit to being completely and utterly blind to the charms, real or otherwise, of Will Farrell.  I can honestly say that this is an actor who has never made me smile, let alone laugh.  But my gut feeling is that he is so inappropriate for this role that even a fan of his would be disappointed.  But the conceit that you could have BEWITCHED and try to shrink her part to that of a necessary but minor character is so silly that it doesn't even bear trying to make sense of.One of the most painful aspects of watching the film is seeing a lot of real talent wasted.  Though Will Farrell remains a complete mystery to me (actually he isn't a mystery:  he is simply awful, but I was being polite), Nicole Kidman, Michael Caine, and Shirley MacLaine are talented individuals.  How is it possible for someone as great as Caine manage to be in THE UGLY AMERICAN one year and BEWITCHED in another?  And what is it with veterans of THE DAILY SHOW?  Awesome show, but Steve Carell and Steve Colbert were stuck in this stinker and Carell has been in several Will Ferrel disasters.  Kristin Chenoweth went from being Glinda the Good Witch in WICKED to a inconsequential supporting role in this one.  And we haven't even gotten into Jason Schwartzman.The lines between Isabel's real life as a witch and the television show get increasingly blurred as the film goes along.  For instance, Aunt Clara shows up as Isabel's real aunt.  And, of course, she concocts a spell that goes awry.Even if the film didn't have all these other problems, there is still the fundamental chemistry between Jack and Isabel, which is to say, there is none.  One just needs to see the horrid scene in which the two of them have dinner overlooking L.A. and Jack sings and then tries to teach Isabel the song he wrote for her.  The entire scene is as flat as a scene can be, one of many that is largely ruined by Ferrel's lack of comic timing.  The timing isn't just Jack and Isabel, but everything in the film.  When the problem is this systemic and all pervasive, the responsibility has to be laid at the feet of the writer and the director.  In this case that would be Nora Ephron, who has in the past shown, of course, great facility in writing.  But whatever magic she possessed while writing WHEN HARRY MET SALLY or SLEEPLESS IN SEATTLE has deserted her in this one.

Renaming the characters and inventing a 'movie' storyline were only two of the problems which I saw while actually watching this movie.Will Ferrell's a decent guy, but Jack Wyatt( who plays 'Darrin') is not supposed to have a 'lead' screen time role in 'Bewitched'. The thrust of the plot needed to be his character reacting to (but not able to stop) what Isabel Bigelow (who plays 'Samantha')does with her powers.Isabel is cast for a 'Bewitched' movie after she is seen wiggling her nose in a local bookstore. The catch for this movie's plotline is that people do not realize that she actually is a witch.Bewitched had worked on the small screen specifically because the original was a metaphor for both interracial marriages and the emergent women's liberation movement. In contrast, the subplot of 'working on a movie set' just gets in the way of what really could have been an awesome screenplay.With vastly increased special effects capabilities now available in the 21st century, the potential for this film was squandered. Ephron and company should be ashamed of themselves for not even attempting to follow the classic TV show. I hope that the people who were involved with that project consider suing this one for property infringement.

reviewText: Will Ferrell and Nicole Kidman star in the new romantic comedy "Bewitched" based on the legendary show from the 60's!!! Isabel is looking for something in her life; something like love. Meanwhile you also have Jack Wyatt( Ferrell) a washed up actor in Hollywood trying to make a big comeback or monopolize on a remake of the show "Bewitched"( very interesting) , for his own selfish reasons. So he is looks for an unknown to play as Samantha, since he is playing as Darwin, who can get the part just write. One day just by magic he finds her, and convinces her to be part of the new "Bewitched" (not knowing she is a witch ) casting her. Isabel mistook by Jack's self centered scheme, feels that he may be the answer to all of her problems.With many unexpected twists and turns, between Isabel's sidesplitting magic and Jack's ,.... well ego they end up falling in love with each other. A lot like Samantha and Darwin went through during the original show. The film is very romantic, hilarious, clever, and something you are sure to love. So the film is basically a romantic comedy like other reviewers said!!!Yet the film isn't perfect,... well nothing is. "Bewitched" at times became a bit to plotty  with too many things happening at once. Along with some boring stretches and some too drawn out or unimportant things added in. The film was still good but it is no masterpiece!!! With an all star cast and a great concept.Overall, I will have to give "Bewitched" a well deserved 3.5/5, a great film make sure to rent!!! reviewText: Bewitched: Bothered and BewilderedThis could have been such a fun romp. It isn't. It's more like a new brand of chewing gum that promises plenty of pizzazz, but quickly loses its flavor.Like her character Isabel, Nicole Kidman has little to do here. What is actually required of her talent is very little compared to her dramatic roles in "The Hours" or even "The Others." There's no reason to doubt her ability to pull off a comedic role, given the right script. Even so, she is beautiful to behold, and despite her character's lack of a personality and literally _unbelievable_ naiveté, Kidman is still worth watching here. (Plus, it's always amazing to hear someone who grew up in Austrailia or Britain acing an American accent -- something that her otherwise-likeable costar Michael Caine unfortunately has never mastered. In this film, as in "The Cider House Rules," I kept wondering what unchartered English-speaking continent Caine's character hailed from.)As for Will Ferrell's role of Jack Wyatt -- unlike Kidman whose acting prowess continues to exceed my expectations in that she can make even empty characters such as Isabel seem at least likeable -- we never really see Ferrell delivering anything but standard Ferrell shtick here, even doing a brief, ironic interview with James Lipton, whom Ferrell has parodied before on Saturday Night Live. As it stands, Ferrell's bumbling character is as clueless as Kidman's - even Jack has to be coached on how to act and react to others, by his annoying agent.For my money, it's Shirley MacLaine who steals every scene she's in. She seems to truly enjoy her part and every time we see her, we can't help but believe Endora is infinitely more interesting and more fun than the characters she supports. With Carole Shelley and Steve Carell channeling the parts of Aunt Clara and Uncle Arthur, this film could have been a consistent hoot and a holler -- if only it'd had a script rather than merely a concept.Also, it's an incredible shame that Jim Carrey wasn't available for the lead role. He could have delivered a great performance while giving an uncanny resemblance to Darren 1, balancing Kidman's surprising resemblance to Samantha here. In Carrey's absence, the writers have Ferrell's character try to justify his own non-resemblance by claiming that audiences of the original series didn't notice the change in actors between Darren 1 and Darren 2, either. Well, yes, actially, we _did_ notice...All-in-all, it's worth a curious look-see, even if repeatedly disappointing. Did I expect a remake of the original series? No. Having seen the previews, I already knew that that wasn't the plot here. Did I expect it to be funny? Yes. And with so much invested in talent and production, I would have thought the effort to create a clever script could have been given priority as well. What instead followed was a hollow pumpkin shell of a premise that was more bothersome and bewildering than bemusing. Even witchcraft couldn't save this film from being little more than left-over Hollywood Halloween candy. As the original Endora might have said, "A pity..."

reviewText: *1/2"Bewitched" is a painfully embarrassing remake of the classic TV sitcom that ran on ABC from 1964-1972.  The series, about a "mixed" marriage between a high-flying sorceress and an earthbound mortal, boasts some of the most familiar and iconic images in television history.Writer Nora Ephron has over-thought the concept to such an extent that she has managed to strip away most of the elements that made the series work in the first place.  The movie isn't technically a "remake" of "Bewitched," since the witch played by Nicole Kidman isn't the Samantha Stevens of the series but rather a single woman named Isabel Bigelow who gets to PLAY Samantha Stephens on TV.  It's all very chic and complicated, you see, but the story goes something like this:  tired of the life of instant gratification that witchcraft so easily affords her, Isabel has decided to strike out on her own  as an utterly self-reliant mortal, moving into a tract home in the San Fernando Valley and vowing to get through the remainder of her days without the benefit of witchcraft.  One afternoon while at a bookstore, she is spotted by one Jack Wyatt, a pompous, self-centered movie actor whose career and personal life have both been in the tank of late and who is hoping to at least jumpstart the former by taking on the role of Darrin Stevens in a new version of the old series.  One glimpse of Isabel's nose-twitching ability convinces him that this non-actress would be perfect for the part, so we wind up, in true Pirandellian fashion, with a fictional TV witch being played by an honest-to-God real life witch.The overriding problem with this film is that it completely undercuts the very elements that made Samantha such a likable and compelling figure for millions of spellbound American viewers.  Even though the character played by Elizabeth Montgomery was basically just a "typical American housewife," content with staying at home and submitting to her husband, she was also intelligent, shrewd, occasionally subversive and always wise to the ways of human nature.  Isabel is none of these things.  In fact, she has been conceived as little more than a dingbat airhead, dippy, goofy and hopelessly backward in her dealings with other people, making us wonder what it was she'd been doing for all the millennia prior to the time of this story.  I doubt Ephron intended for the story to be ironic in this way, but the old Samantha Stevens from 40 years ago came across as a more modern woman then than Isabel does today.  This is clearly Kidman's worst, most annoying performance ever, which only goes to show that even an Academy Award winning actress can't make a silk purse out of every sow's ear that comes her way.  The same goes for Will Ferrell in the role of the pseudo-Darrin whose over-the-top turn here is the movie equivalent of fingernails being dragged across a chalkboard for a grueling one hour and forty minutes (the combined running time of almost four episodes in the original series).  Michael Caine as Isabel's warlock father and Shirley MacLaine as a real life witch who happens to be playing Endora are both old pros enough to turn in decent performances, but even they will undoubtedly want to expunge this turkey from their otherwise illustrious resumes as soon as possible.In the TV "Bewitched," there was a certain subtle tension built into the premise that carried through from episode to episode.  The Stevenses had to find ways to keep the outside world from finding the truth out about Samantha`s real identity, not always an easy task what with Endora or Aunt Clara or Uncle Arthur popping in unannounced at all hours of the day or night casting a spell on some poor, unsuspecting mortal or wreaking havoc on the young couple`s marital harmony and domestic bliss.  This tension is completely lost in the film, as is the conflict between Darrin and Endora that always threatened to end with Darrin being turned into a chimpanzee or a bullfrog and Samantha running back to the effortless ease and comfort of her former existence.  There really is no logical or coherent conflict to speak of in this film, just a lot of people running around acting silly to no discernible point or purpose.  In fact, the only quality scene in the movie is one in which Isabel and Jack are cavorting around an empty set while Frank Sinatra's version of the title song plays in the background.  It turns out to be the one - pardon the pun - "magical" moment in the film.For, astonishingly, even the magic in this film is humdrum compared with the stuff that was done on the TV show.  Someone should inform the makers of this film that special effects have actually advanced some in the last half century.  One would certainly never know it by watching this film.The one positive thing to be said about this movie is that it doesn't come saddled with one of those insipid, mind-numbing laugh tracks that are regularly slapped onto TV sitcoms - but then again even a laugh track wouldn`t find much to chortle over here.
